summary: Email correspondence between Assistant U.S. Attorneys and defense attorney Laura Menninger regarding discovery issues in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, specifically concerning the review of photographic evidence (including thousands of images from Epstein's devices) and physical evidence (boots), logistical arrangements for evidence review in Colorado, and disputes over the designation and handling of 'Highly Confidential' materials.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell; corresponds with prosecutors about discovery review issues, including access to photos and boots, and challenges the 'Highly Confidential' designation of materials.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Contractor for the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York; copied on emails regarding discovery coordination and logistics.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Copied on emails regarding discovery issues; appears to be part of the defense legal team.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as the client of Laura Menninger; defense seeks to review discovery materials with her and notes her right to review evidence.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Mentioned in reference to an order (Dkt. No. 322) that is the subject of a meet-and-confer between prosecution and defense.

connections.description: Menninger is the defense attorney representing Maxwell, advocating for her access to discovery materials and her right to review evidence.
Correspond regarding discovery logistics and deficiencies in the Maxwell case; Menninger makes requests and Pagliuca (on behalf of the prosecution) coordinates responses.
Both are part of the defense legal team for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on discovery-related emails.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Trial date set for November 29, 2021, mentioned in the context of discovery preparation and potential evidence introduction.

events.title: Evidence Review in New York
events.description: Defense counsel Laura Menninger traveled to New York to review evidence, including hard drives containing images from Epstein's devices, but encountered technical issues with accessing files.

events.title: Coordination for Evidence Review in Colorado
events.description: Prosecution informs defense of intent to send boots and hard drives back to New York, prompting defense request to delay shipment to allow more review time in Colorado.

locations: Denver, CO 80203 (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. office)
New York, NY 10007 (U.S. Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York)
Epstein's New York residence (source of seized CDs)
Epstein's private island (mentioned in context of 3D scan files)
keyFacts: The government possessed approximately 40,000 images extracted from CDs seized from Epstein's New York residence, with thousands designated as 'Highly Confidential' due to nudity.

A significant discrepancy existed regarding the count of 'Highly Confidential' images from Epstein's devices: initially estimated at 2,100, but an FBI report indicated approximately 33,747 HC images and 895 HC videos.

Defense attorney Laura Menninger argued that many 'Highly Confidential' designated images contained only adult nudity, not child pornography, and requested copies for proper defense review, challenging the restrictive designation.
Physical evidence, including 'boots' recently taken into evidence, was being transported between New York and Colorado for defense review, with logistical coordination involving FBI agents.

There were widespread technical problems with the discovery production, including corrupt files, unreadable photo formats, missing metadata, and difficulties for the defendant to review materials at the MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center).
